Award.AwardTitle: Capacity Building: Spelman's STEM Teacher Education Pipeline (SSTEP)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
With funding from the National Science Foundation's Robert Noyce Teacher Scholarship Program, this project will address the Nation's growing need to recruit and prepare secondary STEM teachers, but also to provide new teachers with the support that they need to ensure that they remain in the teaching profession. This capacity building project from Spelman College will address the challenges involved in recruiting STEM students into teacher preparation programs. Spelman College has an excellent Secondary STEM Teacher Preparation program; however, no Spelman students, only students from other institutions, have enrolled in that program. In response to the need for effective recruiting, this project will create an avenue for incoming freshman and rising sophomores at Spelman College to follow a recruitment pathway that exposes interested students to STEM education.

The project PI team will create an "Exposure, Exploration, Engagement, and Educator-preparation" pathway for recruiting STEM majors into careers in secondary STEM teaching. Each step of the capacity building pathway reinforces students' understanding of the intricacies involved in becoming a STEM educator. The elements of the program have all been demonstrated to be effective mechanisms for the recruitment of students into teaching. The first element is exposure to STEM teaching through informational sessions and workshops describing STEM education and research in STEM education. Students then explore STEM teaching through positions as undergraduate teaching assistants (UTAs). Finally they are engaged in STEM education and research through a STEM Undergraduate Research Educator (SURE) summer program. This recruitment pathway leads the students into the culmination of the process, formal educator-preparation through the Spelman secondary education program. The formal evaluation plan of the project is providing knowledge that will inform successful recruitment of STEM students into STEM teaching, particularly the recruitment of women and minority students, into programs across the nation. One indicator regarding the success of this pipeline will be viewed through the number of students enrolling in Spelman's Orientation to Education course, a mandatory class needed before a student can apply to the teacher certification program.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes Summary

NSF 1439757 Robert Noyce Teacher Scholarship Program

Title: Capacity Building:  Spelman’s STEM Teacher Education Pipeline (SSTEP)

 

Shannon Sung, Viveka (Borum) Brown, Spelman College

Spelman’s Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (STEM) Teacher Education Pipeline was developed to create a pathway to support the recruitment of undergraduate minority students to teach STEM courses, and to increase the number of women and minorities who teach in the STEM education field.  The pipeline did not only establish an interdisciplinary collaboration between STEM and Education faculty but also the partnership with the  local school district and summer camp.  We attempted to create a sustainable mechanism that could help us identify prospective teacher candidates from STEM majors to pursue teaching professions and become competent in conducting action research.

 

Forty six students participated in at least one of the following activities:  information sessions on math and science education, interdisciplinary faculty mentoring experiences in classroom settings, mini-research projects serving as summer STEM camp educators, and networking opportunities through attending various STEM and education conferences.  The information sessions exposed interested STEM majors not only to our project opportunities but also provided information about admission and educational requirements for secondary chemistry, physics, and mathematics teacher certification programs. STEM and education faculty provided mentoring to the participants serving as undergraduate teaching assistants (UTAs) through observation, assistance in the respective classes and by offering and sharing tips for tutoring sessions. STEM camp educators were provided a four-week hands-on research experience in secondary STEM education through working with middle and high school students from the local area.  The program directors hosted group meetings with the UTAs throughout the semester to provide the UTAs opportunities to share individual student observations in the respective STEM classrooms, provide interaction with mentors and share tips for tutoring sessions. Two of the program participants conducted educational research projects and presented their findings at national and regional mathematics and science conferences, while a conversation among education and STEM departments was created to better identify interested prospective teacher candidates.  Thirteen participants attended math and science conferences to network with other STEM professionals.

After participation in the program, three participants have either completed or are currently enrolled in a gateway course for entry into teaching, and one has chosen education as her minor. In addition, one student is a recipient of Woodrow Wilson Teaching Fellowship and many others are looking for opportunities to continue their influence in STEM education either at varying education levels from middle school to higher education. Many of the program alumna are currently enrolled in master's or Ph.D. programs pursuing advanced degrees while serving as teaching assistants or tutors. The survey results indicated that the engagement in the program has enhanced their willingness to consider teaching as a profession; however, they reported some existing obstacles that prevent them from successfully completing the teaching certification program in four years. We plan to follow up with these alumna and engage in longitudinal study to determine their career path.
